J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> I admit that, in the case of the classloader fix, the JUnit leaders are 
> being unnecessarily slow. Let me see whether I can do something about that.

Slow? I don't think that's the issue!


> How many such fixes are there, though, really? There's the classloader 
> fix, and the string compares fix, and other than that, everything else 
> is merely an extension, isn't it? (I'm talking about DbUnit, HtmlUnit, 
> HttpUnit, XMLUnit, ...)

How many is a red herring.


>>I'd direct you to Ant as an example of an open source project that
>>accepts contributions; a project by the way that probably has more
>>users that Junit but is at least being actively improved and worked on.
> 
> 
> Agreed. 

Ok.

> Ant is also huge and complicated, compared to JUnit.

And has more uses. And yet, I have no more wrapper code for Ant than 
I have for JUnit. But you're talking technology and features here; 
I'm talking about how to manage and maintain an open source project.

cheers
Bill
